Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 6-10, more toward the end of the semester when many elements of the group project were due.

Before Spring break/before data analysis -- max 2 hours per week
After Spring break/after starting data analysis -- 3-4 hours per week
2-3 on average
Much of our work for this class was done outside of class. Our group met almost every Tuesday afternoon for 1.5-2 hours to complete our project.
5-10 depending on the assignments that week.
Anywhere between 2 - 15, depending on the assignment due.
Hours per week varied depending on the assignment. Data analysis took longer
5 hours per week
5-15 (more when projects were due)
Consider team meetings about 2 hours every time we met.
2hrs
5-7 hours (depending on how much group assignments that week)

This course was great. I essentially learned by doing and had a great end product to show for it. However, I wish I would have learned how to use SPSS and run factor, reliability, and validity assessments more in-depth. I would have liked to go deeper into the theory behind these questionnaire evaluations.

This course is extremely valuable for all students, whether or not you're planning to go into research. Although working in a group for the whole semester is challenging at times, it's necessary given the format of this course, since it would be unrealistic for us to each do a complete project on our own. However, I wish the groups were capped at 4-5 people, as some were as large as 8, which can be extremely chaotic. The information taught is well-presented and helpful, but it would be much easier if we were taught SPSS toward the beginning of the semester rather than trying to learn it on the fly while we're doing our actual data analysisbecause nobody had any SPSS experience prior to when we were supposed to analyze our data, many members of the groups worked 15-20+ hours/week on the assignment during that period due to the extremely steep learning curve. This would be remedied by this content being taught earlier in the semester.

This course was good.  The course was very engaging and hands on.  The one criticism I have is group selection in the beginning of the semester.  Marney should step in to ensure that groups are a more uniform size.  Some groups were very small while some groups were very large, and I believe this created unfair workload differences between groups.  Large groups had trouble managing many members while small groups had more work to do.  Group sizes should be standardized.  Other than that, great course.
Wish that the course provided more insight or knowledge on analyzing the results.
great!

In class time often seemed ineffective. We didn't quite reach the crux of the material until well past spring break, at which point we were already winding down and preparing for the final deliverables.

strengths: possible to develop a publishable project if your team is equally passionate about a specific topic, learn SPSS through your own data collected if you take the time to explore its features independently
weaknesses: scattered lecture presentations with tangents that detract from understanding QD, unclear understanding of the topic as a whole, had to set up weekly group meetings outside of class to actually complete the work
Great learning experience

Strengths: you'll learn qualtrics and SPSS, which are useful skills. Learning to build surveys and questionnaires are really helpful in study design methods, so if you'll work or do additional courses that include this, this is a worthwhile course to take to learn a hard, useful skill.
Weaknesses: group work can be challenging at times. Having more support for how to structure the work from the professor would have helped. Learning more SPSS would also be helpful (some students had it available through Citrix, others didn't and had to rely on computers on campus, and as a result, some are able to learn more than others).

I really enjoyed this course! Marney is a wonderful lecturer, and I was excited to take a class on questionnaire design. I wish we had spent more time actually going over how to use SPSS - this was done on our own, which was okay, but some parts proved tricky (and a brief overview would have been great). I wish we had spent more time on certain topics, too, like examples of what not to do on scales (although good examples were provided - these just seemed a little quick).
Good course, able to learn more about survey and questionnaire development. Would've liked more time on the data analysis lecture (validity, etc.)
More structured lectures would be nice as well as more guidance on the more difficult concepts related to survey analysis.

Strengths - interesting topic, cool project getting to choose and work through building a whole questionnaire, Marney is very entertaining, enthusiastic, and knowledgeable.
Weaknesses - I think the class size was a bit too large for everybody to be as engaged/get a lot out of the course. I think it would be better if each student had the change to speak directly with Marney or the TF more regularly, and/or if there were more discussions/engagement built into the course!

I enjoyed Questionaire Development. The structure of the course provided a number of opportunities to engage with the coursework, including critical analysis, evaluating previous research, collaborating in a group setting, and formal presentation.

This class was SO useful! The skills of questionnaire development and validation using statistical analysis packages will serve me throughout my career. It had just the right amount of individual and group assignments.
This course is awesome. Super helpful.

Great course to learn about into survey/questionnaire design and methods. It was larger this year than anticipated, and I think that really impacted the structure and feel of the course. In the future it would be nice if this class could remain a smaller, interactive, seminar-style course with smaller groups for the project (it's hard to coordinate and work on a group project with 6 people and feel that you are all contributing equally, and also writing with 6 people and combing 6 different people's writing is tricky...).

Developing and validating a questionnaire with a group makes it extremely feasible. I don't think any of my group members were actually stressed about the workload this semester, and we got to do something that we enjoyed, which made this whole process of learning about psychometrics and what a "good" survey actually is, a whole lot more fun and engaging.
Honestly I loved this class for the material, the skills I gained, Marney and Adam! I have no complaints about the class itself.

This course walked us through the process and theory behind building a questionnaire on a subject and population of our choice. The lectures were helpful when it came to descriptions of the different concepts we would be exploring, but they were not very helpful when it came to actually doing the project. I felt as though, in addition to the skills gained and applied in the construction of the questionnaire, there could have been more emphasis on navigating group dynamics and how responsibilities and roles could be delineated when approaching a large project like this. My experience in the class would have been substantially more fruitful if my group's dynamics were more productive and involved less hostility or conflict.

Strength: Adam (the TA), The group projects

Weakness:  The course material was not well organized especially during the 2nd half of the course.
The 2nd half of the course had a high proportion of specialized topics to learn and not as much time was devoted to it .

Strengths: practical, hands-on course about making and developing a questionnaire/survey that can be used for research. Basic introduction to using SPSS and Qualtrics

Weaknesses: wish there time for a more in-depth teaching of SPSS for data analysis
Dr. White is very high energy and engaging. Loved having her as a professor.
Marney is excellent, I highly recommend taking any course that she is teaching. She is very knowledgeable and makes learning potentially dull content fun and interesting.

Marney was great.  She was incredibly invested and interested in this course.  She would play with the student data for her own pure interest and give us more ideas for our projects.  She is truly passionate about this course.  She provided a chill environment where we were comfortable asking questions and providing feedback.
love marney!

clearly understands the topic and is eager to help projects excel
however, her approach to teaching and communication to students can be unprofessional
Shes an amazing person and a great professor

Marney is an amazing professor. You'll learn so much from her. I especially like how she brings in real-life examples from her work so you can learn best practices. She covers the material in a very engaging way that makes class fun. She also provides in-depth feedback on assignments, which I found very helpful.
Marney is a wonderful human -- so thoughtful, funny, empathetic, and intelligent. Deeply thankful to have had the opportunity to have been in her course.
Good professor, funny, engaging.
Marney is very kind and knowledgeable about this topic area. She is approachable but very busy so it can be hard to get a hold of her.
Marney is very enthusiastic, kind, and knowledgeable!
Marney was a great instructor. She is friendly, passionate, and personable.
Dr. White was an amazing instructor and so helpful throughout the course as we were developing our survey!
Marney is a great instructor. really cares about students learning and pursuing their interests in this course.

Marney is fabulous!! 10/10 would recommend her as an instructor and would love to see more classes taught by Marney (maybe Intro to SPSS Methods? SPSS for SBS?). She is always helpfully critical and thoughtful with our work and ideas and helped drive our projects forward with consistent enthusiasm and genuine caring for our work and success.
Incredible. Shes such a kind and caring instructor. Her quirkiness and teachable moments got me through a tough semester.
Truly a pleasure learning from Marney. Very engaged with the students and encouraging of our questionnaire pursuits.
10/10 would recommend

The instructor was approachable when our groups had any questions at any point in the process of our project. The lectures did involve a lot of just listening to concept definitions and not a lot of applied skill, which would have been useful. Most of the guidance we got for our project came from actual discussions with the instructor or TF rather than from the lecture slides. Attending the lectures was not particularly beneficial to me, but the discussions among our group and with the instructors really defined our project and any steps we made forward.

She created conducive leaning environment and make the class fun.
She however could be more organized in the way she presents the information, particularly the information in the 2nd half of the class on  data analysis

Marney is very passionate and knowledgeable about psychometric properties of surveys and designing surveys. She was instrumental for helping individual groups design the survey.

The organization for the class could have been better. There were some assignments that were due before the material was taught in class. There were also a lot of resources for the class but where it was located on Canvas was difficult to navigate.
Great course to learn how to develop a survey in, because you literally develop a survey.
Highly recommend! Although be aware that it is completely group-based, so make sure you choose people with whom you work well/who will contribute equally to the outcomes.

I would recommend this course.  I will warn that the majority of the class is one large group project with small group assignments due most weeks with occasional individual assignments.  The group work is very fair, but experiences will vary based on quality of the group.  Marney does well checking in to make sure all members are doing their part.
it was a great class for Q development .
Take it. You learn so much
If you want to learn how to create surveys and questionnaires, as well as how to critically evaluate scales out there, this is a great class to take to learn a hard skill.
Take it! Great course!! Loved it!
Good course to take, especially if there's a topic you're passionate about and would like to study it with a questionnaire.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in public health practice or research. Survey design will be a very useful skill set to have.
A great course to learn how to build a questionnaire, a useful skill. Would recommend!

I would recommend this course for fellow students. Questionnaire development is a helpful skill to have, even for students in concentrations outside of SBS. Identifying valid questionnaire structure and psychometric properties provides critical thinking when we are exposed to other questionnaires.

This class is an absolute must for any student who might have to design a survey in their career. It teaches you how to build a survey, validate it, analyze the results, and create a manuscript which can be published.
really fun course with a chill workload.

This course was a nice intro to learning about questionnaire/survey design and methods, and while it was larger than the previous years and the group project was tricky to coordinate, it was still a nice class to learn SPSS and Qualtrics -- and Marney is wonderful!! If for nothing else, take this course for Marney and to learn SPSS (both will change your life).
Yes! I had to work with a survey for data analysis in another class, and after taking this course, I was also be pinpoint all the ways that made this other survey a terrible measurement tool.

This is a great course and a lot of fun, but please be cautious of the group you pick. The group can make or break your entire semester and your experience. Marney is wonderful and the skills you gain are so useful? But your sanity needs to be in consideration too when you pick the group, because you rely on them for everything.

This course gave a broad overview of how to construct, distribute, and analyze a questionnaire of our choice. I personally did not have a positive experience with my group, I believe that the skills that were taught and gained throughout the process can be beneficial for students who want to continue quantitative research in their careers or the future.

Good class.  I didn't realize till the very end of the class that the class actually focuses on questionnaire  VALIDATION. When i initially took the class i thought it was going to teach me how to create good questionnaires- it doesn't. This was my fault but don't make the same mistake. Still, i try to make use of my new found skill on questionnaire VALIDATION.

A good practical course that gives hands-on experience for learning about, developing, distributing, and analyzing data from questionnaires. 

I would recommend to anyone who is going to do survey research and wants some hands-on experience with Qualtrics.
